channel.title: Comments on: Let’s Talk About Taix
channel.description: Blogging demolitions one building at a time.

item.title: By: curious1
item.dc:creator: curious1
item.description: I'm so crushed by the pending loss of so many collective memories and the erasure of this establishment. There was originally talk of maintaining the facade & porte cohere along with the front rooms for some historic preservation but this seems to have disappeared. Now we have another banal unimaginative and expensive building that could be anywhere.... a real tragedy!
item.content:encoded:
I’m so crushed by the pending loss of so many collective memories and the erasure of this establishment. There was originally talk of maintaining the facade & porte cohere along with the front rooms for some historic preservation but this seems to have disappeared.
Now we have another banal unimaginative and expensive building that could be anywhere…. a real tragedy!

item.title: By: John Steppling
item.dc:creator: John Steppling
item.description: ok, its ONE of the things turning the culture into a wasteland. I was just reading Tafuri on the Seagrams Building. Oddly that somehow feels relevant.
item.content:encoded: ok, its ONE of the things turning the culture into a wasteland. I was just reading Tafuri on the Seagrams Building. Oddly that somehow feels relevant.

item.title: By: John Steppling
item.dc:creator: John Steppling
item.description: seriously, I ask this seriously...why are curbed readers such douches? I went to Taix's (sic) with my dad in the late 50s. It was cool then and its cool now. The soul deadening architecture of what laughingly passes for affordable apartment space is what is making American culture a wasteland of banality.
item.content:encoded: seriously, I ask this seriously…why are curbed readers such douches? I went to Taix’s (sic) with my dad in the late 50s. It was cool then and its cool now. The soul deadening architecture of what laughingly passes for affordable apartment space is what is making American culture a wasteland of banality.

item.title: By: C.C.
item.dc:creator: C.C.
item.description: <p>The Taix family have a history of serving on the board of the French Benevolent Society – they of the missing $33+ million dollar nest egg. The recent sale of Taix may not be entirely coincidental.</p>
item.content:encoded: The Taix family have a history of serving on the board of the French Benevolent Society – they of the missing $33+ million dollar nest egg. The recent sale of Taix may not be entirely coincidental.
